Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Engineering and Nanoscience of Materials and Device Applications in Biotechnology and Medicine

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program hosted by the NanoScience Technology Center (NSTC) at the University of Central Florida (UCF), entitled, "Engineering and Nanoscience of Materials and Device Applications in Biotechnology and Medicine", will engage a diverse cohort of students, recruited from underrepresented groups, in the development of materials and technologies for application in biotechnology and medicine. The students will gain hands-on research training in topics such as adoptive cancer immunotherapy and targeted nanoparticle cancer therapy, engineering of MEMS devices and body-on-a-chip systems for proteomics research, develop nanofibers for tissue engineering, engineer smart wound healing patches, and nanomanufacturing of tunable plasmonic sensors. The REU site will foster intercollegial relationships between faculty and students with an opportunity to investigate new teaching and training paradigms. The program further strengthens bridges to community colleges in Central Florida and minority institutions with limited research capabilities by promoting the benefits of undergraduate research. This REU experience will inspire students to pursue careers that produce high quality researchers and personnel, which will help address the growing need for trained professionals capable of developing and deploying biotechnology and the next generation of medicine in the field.

Each undergraduate student will conduct research over a ten week summer experience with a multidisciplinary team of faculty and students. The program will also include: (1) Introductory Course in Engineering, Nanoscience and Technology; (2) Mentor and student professional development, including leadership and diversity; (3) Writing Across the Curriculum (WAC), scientific writing development for REU students; (4) Seminars, workshops, group projects to foster interdisciplinary research and learning; (5) Monitoring, evaluation, and tracking of the students' progress via weekly discussion groups; and (6) Preparation of students to pursue careers in STEM and medical areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF REU Site on ?Engineering and Nanoscience of Materials and Device Applications in Biotechnology and Medicine? is hosted by the NanoScience Technology Center (NSTC) at the University of Central Florida (UCF). The participating undergraduate students worked in a university research lab setting. They were exposed to science and technologies related to STEM disciplines under the mentorship of university research faculty and collaboration with graduate students. Students were trained in topics such as adoptive cancer immunotherapy and targeted nanoparticle cancer therapy, engineering of MEMs devices and body-on-a-chip systems for proteomics research, develop nanofibers for tissue engineering, engineer smart wound healing patches, and nanomanufacturing of tunable plasmonic sensors. The research involved experimental work as well as computer based modeling. REUs were trained in technology commercialization of nanomaterials for enabling technology in collaboration with UCF?s Technology Incubator. This experience will aid students in formulating their career paths in STEM areas not only in academics but also industry and will create a multi-cultural rich environment for the students to enable them to understand the intercultural dynamics in a research, manufacturing and educational settings.

Diversity of the participating students was a point of emphasis of this REU site. Cumulatively, 37 students from 23 schools (a few examples: University of Illinois at Chicago, Georgia Tech, University of Louisiana at Lafayette, University of Central Florida, University of Dallas, Valencia College, Johns Hopkins University, Inter American University of Puerto Rico (Bayamon Campus), University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez, Clemson University, Polytechnic University of Puerto Rico (San Juan Campus), Harvard University) participated in the REU. We also supported 2 teachers for summer research experiences. From this group 32 of the participants are considered to be from underrepresented groups in engineering, from a total of 39 participants, which corresponds to over 82%.

Several instruments for participating faculty and for participating students were utilized to obtain primary data for evaluation of our program. The evaluation instruments rendered a mechanism to assess student?s perceptions of their scientific leadership. Faculty observations of student development and research self-efficacy also were evaluated. Students showed most improvement in the areas of technical skills, organization skills, written expression, problem solving, breadth and application of knowledge, formulating own research question, working with others, resourcefulness, and performance on task.

So far REU students and RET are involved in 9 published papers. REU students, RET, and faculty also presented 47 papers in REU poster symposium (39 posters) and 8 conference presentations (such as: IWAC 2018, 8th World Congress on Particle Technology, NanoFlorida, Meeting of International Society for Cellular Therapy, Sustainable Nanotechnology Organization). The students won prestigious awards ranging from presentation awards to fellowships and scholarships, including NSF?s Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP).

We have tracked the career paths of our REU students closely since we first started the program. Out of the graduates 50% joined in graduate school (Emory University, Columbia University, Georgia Institute of Tech, Fairleigh Dickinson U, U. of Washington, U. of Arizona, etc). Of students that haven?t graduated yet over 75% are intending to go for Ph.D. or Medical school.
